markdownRemark.html:
There are things that remind you of your youth. I have a lot of them. But nothing gets me back to those carefree days (more) than this poem :).

When I read this, I remembered things. The aroma of cafeteria soup ,ready for recess time, squeezing through the windows while I raise my hand to make like a tree. I see a glimpse of the quadrangle, how it excites me to play again later with my friends, when I opened my mouth and shouted out the title. I hear the laughter of my classmates while I stumbled on the first stanza. Feel still the sweat forming on my forehead when I forgot the next one. And I still feel accomplishment when I finally did remember and finished reciting with claps all around.

I love this poem. Not because its the best written or its the first I recited. I love it because it’s one of those things that paints back pictures of good times, sometimes more clearly than what happened 5 minutes ago. I’m growing old I guess. Nostalgia becomes staple like hot coffee. Anyway, here’s the poem – Enjoy!

Maybe someday I can teach this to my children.

P.S. Lets plant more trees. Help Mother Earth!

Joyce Kilmer. 1886–1918
<119.>
I THINK that I shall never see
A poem lovely as a tree.
A tree whose hungry mouth is prest
Against the sweet earth’s flowing breast;
A tree that looks at God all day,
And lifts her leafy arms to pray;
A tree that may in summer wear
A nest of robins in her hair;
Upon whose bosom snow has lain;
Who intimately lives with rain.
Poems are made by fools like me,
But only God can make a tree.

From bartleby.com
